definitions.definition: to give somebody official permission to leave the police or the armed forces; to make somebody leave the police or the armed forces

examples.text: He was discharged from the army following his injury.
She was discharged from the police force for bad conduct.
He was found guilty and dishonourably discharged from the army.

definitions.definition: to allow somebody to leave hospital because they are well enough to leave

examples.text: Patients were being discharged from the hospital too early.
All the people involved in the accident have now been discharged from hospital.
She had discharged herself against medical advice.

definitions.definition: to allow somebody to leave prison or court

examples.text: He was **conditionally discharged** after admitting the theft.
She was formally discharged by the court.

definitions.definition: to allow a member of a jury to stop serving in a court case

examples.text: If the jury cannot agree, it should be discharged.
The judge took the unusual step of discharging the entire jury halfway through the trial.

definitions.definition: when a gas or a liquid discharges or is discharged, or somebody discharges it, it flows somewhere

examples.text: The river is diverted through the power station before discharging into the sea.
The factory was fined for discharging chemicals into the river.
Raw sewage was discharged from the treatment plant directly into the river.

definitions.definition: if part of the body discharges something, a liquid such as pus comes out of it

examples.text: The wound started discharging pus.
Lightning is caused by clouds discharging electricity.

definitions.definition: to do everything that is necessary to perform and complete a particular duty

examples.text: to **discharge your duties/responsibilities/obligations**
to **discharge a debt** *(= to pay it)*
I will faithfully discharge my duties.
His widow was unable to discharge the debt.
My condition renders me unable to discharge my duties.
He could not properly discharge his duties.

definitions.definition: to fire a gun, etc.; (of a gun, etc.) to be fired

examples.text: The police officer accidentally discharged a firearm while unloading it.
They gave a cheer and charged, discharging a volley of arrows as they came.
He knocked her hand down and the gun discharged into the floor.

wordOrigin: Middle English (in the sense ‘relieve of (an obligation)’): from Old French descharger, from late Latin discarricare ‘unload’, from dis- (expressing reversal) + carricare, carcare ‘to load’, from Latin carrus ‘wheeled vehicle’.
